facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 107 of 1952 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 107 of 1952. Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated 22nd March, 1951,

facts.text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated 22nd March, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta by Harries C.J. and Banerjee J. in Reference No. 4 of 1950 in Civil Rule No. 1643 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the Judgment and Order dated 22nd March, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature at Calcutta  Harries C.J. and Banerjee J.  in Reference No. 4 of 1950 .in .Civil Rule No. 1643 Of 1950.

facts.text: The first respondent purchased the entire Touzi No. 341 of the 24-Parganas Collectorate at a revenue sale held on January 9, 1942.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent herein  hereinafter referred to as the respondent  purchased the entire Touzi No. 341 of the 24-Parganas Collectorate at a revenue sale held on ,January 9, 1942.

facts.text: As purchaser, the respondent acquired under section 37 of the Bengal Revenue Sales Act, 1859 the right to avoid and annul all under-tenures and forthwith to eject all under-tenants with certain exceptions.

anchor.surface_text: As such purchaser, the respondent acquired under section 37 of the Bengal Revenue Sales Act, 1859  Central Act No. 11 of 1859  the right to avoid and annul all under-tenures and forthwith to eject all under-tenants-with certain exceptions which are number material here.

facts.text: In exercise of that right the respondent gave notices of ejectment and brought a suit in 1946 to evict certain under-tenants, including the second respondent herein.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of that right the respondent gave numberices of ejectment and brought a suit in 1946 to evict certain under-tenants, including the second respondent herein, and to recover possession of. the lands.

facts.text: The suit was decreed against the second respondent who preferred an appeal to the District Judge, 24-Parganas.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was. decreed against the second respondent who preferred an appeal to the District Judge, 24-Parganas, Contending that his undertenure came within one of the exceptions referred to in section 37.

facts.text: When the appeal was pending, the Bill for West Bengal Revenue Sales (West Bengal Amendment) Act, 1950 was introduced in the West Bengal Legislative Assembly on March 23, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: When the appeal was pending, the Bill, which was later passed as the West Bengal Revenue Sales  West . Bengal Amendment  Act, 1950,  hereinafter referred to asthe amending Act  was introduced in the West Bengal Legislative Assembly on March 23, 1950.

facts.text: The amending Act came into force on March 15, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Bill was eventually passed as the amending Act and it .came into force on.March 15, 1950.

facts.text: Section 7 of the amending Act provided that all pending suits, appeals and other proceedings which had not already resulted in delivery of possession shall abate.

anchor.surface_text: It substituted by section 4 thenew section 37 in the place of the original section 37, and it provided by section 7 that all pending suits, appeals and other proceedings which had number already resulted in delivery of possession shall abate.

facts.text: The respondent moved the High Court under article 228 to withdraw the pending appeal and determine the constitutional issue raised by him.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the respondent, companytending that section 7 wasvoid as abriging his fundamental fights under article 19 1   f  and article 31, moved the High Court under article 228 to withdraw the pending appeal and determine the companystitutional issue .raised by him.

facts.text: The appeal was withdrawn and the case was heard by Trevor Harries C.J. and Banerjee J.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal accordingly. withdrawn and the case was heard by Trevor Harries C.J. and Banerjee J who, by separate but, companycurring judgments,

facts.text: High Court declared section 7 unconstitutional and void and returned the case to the District Court.

anchor.surface_text: who, by separate but, companycurring judgments, declared section 7 unconstitutional and void and. returned the case to the District Court for disposal, in companyformity with their decision.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 17, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: 1953. December 17. The following Judgments were delivered.

facts.text: Subodh Gopal Bose annulled all under-tenures and tenancies appertaining to the said Touzi.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of his rights under the section set out above, the respondent Subodh Gopal Bose annulled all under-tenures and tenancies appertaining to the said Touzi and on tile 18th March, 1946,

facts.text: On 18th March, 1946, instituted Title Suit No. 35 of 1946 in the Fourth Court of the Subordinate Judge at Alipore for ejectment of respondents Nos. 2 to 6.

anchor.surface_text: and on tile 18th March, 1946, instituted a suit, being Title Suit No. 35 of 1946, in the Fourth Court of the Subordinate Judge at Alipore 24-Parganahs for the ejectment of respondents Nos. 2 to 6,

facts.text: Subordinate Judge delivered judgment on 14th February, 1949, decreed ejectment against defendant No.1 (respondent No.2).

anchor.surface_text: The learned Subordinate Judge who tried the suit delivered his judgment on the 14th February, 1949. By that judgment he overruled the companytentions of the companytesting defendant and passed a decree for ejectment against him.

facts.text: Respondent No.2 preferred appeal Title Appeal No. 252 of 1949 on 25th March, 1949 before District Judge at Alipore.

anchor.surface_text: On the 25th March, 1949, the respondent No. 2 preferred an appeal, being Title Appeal No. 252 of 1949, before the District Judge at Alipore, 24Parganahs.

facts.text: Appeal transferred to Additional District Judge.

anchor.surface_text: That appeal was transferred to the companyrt of the Additional District Judge for hearing.

facts.text: West Bengal Act VII of 1950 assented by Governor on 15th March, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: which received the assent of the Governor of Bengal on the 15th March, 1950, and was published in the Official Gazette on the day.

facts.text: On 21st July, 1950, respondent applied to Additional District Judge for reference under article 228.

anchor.surface_text: On the 21st July, 1950, the respondent Subodh Gopal Bose applied before the Additional District Judge before whom the appeal was pending to make a reference under article 228 of the Constitution of India

facts.text: Additional District Judge dismissed application on 16th September, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional District Judge by his order dated the 16th September, 1950, dismissed that application.

facts.text: On 24th November, 1950, respondent applied to High Court under article 228.

anchor.surface_text: On the 24th November, 1950,the respondent Subodh Gopal Bose applied to the High Court under article 228

facts.text: On 18th December, 1950, High Court directed appeal transferred to itself as Reference Case No. 4 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and eventually on the 18th December, 1950, the High Court directedthe appeal to be transferred to the High Court only for the decision of the companystitutional point. The proceedings were numbered as Reference Case No. 4 of 1950.

facts.text: High Court on 22nd March, 1951 held section 7 void under article 19(1)(f) and 19(5).

anchor.surface_text: On the 22nd March, 1951, the High Court held that section 7 imposed an unreasonable restriction on the respondent Subodh Gopal Boses right to hold property and violated his fundamental right guaranteed by article 19  1   f  read with article 19  5  and was, therefore void under article 13  1 .

facts.text: On 30th November, 1951, High Court gave leave to State of West Bengal to appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: On the 30th November, 1951, the High Court gave leave to the State of West Bengal to appeal to us.

issues.text: Whether Section 7 of the West Bengal Revenue Sales (Amendment) Act, 1950 is void as abridging fundamental rights under Article 19(1)(f)?

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the respondent, companytending that section 7 wasvoid as abriging his fundamental fights under article 19 1   f  and article 31, moved the High Court under article 228 to withdraw the pending appeal

issues.text: Whether Section 7 of the West Bengal Revenue Sales (Amendment) Act, 1950 is void as abridging fundamental rights under Article 31?

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the respondent, companytending that section 7 wasvoid as abriging his fundamental fights under article 19 1   f  and article 31, moved the High Court under article 228 to withdraw the pending appeal

issues.text: Whether the respondent's right to annul under-tenures and evict under-tenants is a vested right under Article 19(1)(f), and whether Section 7 imposes an unreasonable restriction thereon under Article 19(5)?

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held that the respondents right to annul under-tenures and evict under-tenants being a vested right acquired by him under his purchase before section 37 was amended

issues.text: If the right claimed is property under Article 19(1)(f), is it also property under Article 31(1), such that deprivation by Section 7 is lawful as by authority of law?

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant State the learned Attorney-General companytended before uS that if, as the respondent claims, his right to annul under-tenures and. evict under-tenants in occupation other than those protected under the original enactment, was property within the meaning of clause  1  Of article 19

issues.text: Whether Article 19(1)(f) protects the general freedom/capacity of citizens to acquire, hold and dispose of property, or concrete rights to specific property (as opposed to Article 31)?

anchor.surface_text: then, it was also property within the meaning of clause  1  of article 31, as the expression must have the sameconnotation in both the provisions, and the respondent, having been deprived of it under the authority of law, namely, section 7 of the amending Act, such deprivation was lawful

issues.text: Whether clauses (1) and (2) of Article 31 are mutually exclusive (deprivation under (1) without compensation unless acquisition/possession under (2)), or to be read together?

anchor.surface_text: Article 31 1  formulates the fundamental right in negative form prohibiting the deprivation of property except by authority of law. It implies that a person may be deprived of his property by authority of law. Article 31 2  prohibits the acquisition or taking possession of property for a public purpose under any law

issues.text: Whether Section 7 read with Section 4 of the amending Act infringes the fundamental right under Article 31?

anchor.surface_text: On this view of the meaning and effect of article 31, the question is whether section 7 read with section 4 of the amending Act infringes the fundamental right of the respondent under that article.

issues.text: Does the abridgement by Section 7 amount to deprivation of property within the meaning of Article 31 as interpreted?

anchor.surface_text: Does such abridgement amount to deprivation of property within the meaning of article 31 as interpreted above

issues.text: If deprivation under Article 31, does it fall within the exception in clause (5)(b)(ii)?

anchor.surface_text: does it fall within the exception in clause  5   b   ii  of that article ?

issues.text: Whether the retrospective operation of Section 7 renders the restriction unreasonable under Article 19(5)?

anchor.surface_text: section 7 imposed an unreasonable restriction on the respondent Subodh Gopal Boses right to hold property and violated his fundamental right guaranteed by article 19  1   f  read with article 19  5

arguments.claim: Section 7 of the amending Act is void as abridging fundamental rights under Article 19(1)(f) and Article 31

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon, the respondent, contending that section 7 was void as abridging his fundamental rights under article 19(1)(f) and article 31, moved the High Court under article 228 to withdraw the pending appeal and determine the constitutional issue raised by him.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y clause  5  of that article and was void. On behalf of the appellant State the learned Attorney-General companytended before uS that if, as the respo

arguments.court_reasoning: Article 19(1)(f) protects general capacity to hold property, not concrete rights; Article 31 applies but no deprivation

arguments.claim: Respondent's right to annul under-tenures and evict under-tenants is a vested right acquired before amendment; retrospective deprivation without price abatement infringes Article 19(1)(f) and is not saved by Article 19(5)

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held that the respondents right to annul under-tenures and evict under-tenants being a vested right acquired by him under his purchase before section 37 was amended, the retrospective deprivation of that right by section 7 of the amending Act without any abatement of the price paid by the respondent at the revenue sale was an infringement of his fundamental right under article 19(1)(f) to hold property with all the rights acquired under his purchase, and as such deprivation was not a reasonable restriction on the respondents exercise of his vested right, section 7 was not saved by clause (5) of that article and was void.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: aseprivileges and immunities in the companytext of thoseprovisions which, according to some of the Judges,have a reference only to those privileges an

arguments.court_reasoning: Article 19(1)(f) does not apply to concrete property rights; restriction reasonable under circumstances

arguments.claim: If the right to annul under-tenures is property under Article 19(1)(f), it is also property under Article 31(1); deprivation by authority of law (section 7) is lawful

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant State the learned Attorney-General contended before us that if, as the respondent claims, his right to annul under-tenures and evict under-tenants in occupation other than those protected under the original enactment, was property within the meaning of clause (1) Of article 19, then, it was also property within the meaning of clause (1) of article 31, as the expression must have the same connotation in both the provisions, and the respondent, having been deprived of it under the authority of law, namely, section 7 of the amending Act, such deprivation was lawful

court_response_anchor.surface_text: y clause  5  of that article and was void. On behalf of the appellant State the learned Attorney-General companytended before uS that if, as the respo

arguments.court_reasoning: Accepts same connotation but holds Article 19(1)(f) inapplicable to concrete rights; proceeds to Article 31 interpretation

arguments.claim: Nullification of right is reasonable restriction on property enjoyment under Article 19(5) in interests of general public, considering statement of objects and reasons

anchor.surface_text: Alternatively, it was urged that if the correct view was that the nullification of the respondents right was only the imposition of a restriction on the enjoyment of the property purchased by him, as has been held by the learned Judges below, then, it was a reasonable restriction imposed in the interests of the general public under clause (5) of article 19, having regard to the facts and circumstances which led to the enactment of the measure as disclosed in the Statement of Objects and Reasons annexed to the Bill

court_response_anchor.surface_text: t is why presumably numberconstitutional protection is provided against the exercise of that power. But fundamental rights under the Constitution stan

arguments.court_reasoning: Das J accepts after considering circumstances like hardships in urban areas, ordinance, pending cases, rent enhancement

arguments.claim: Article 19(1)(f) declares general freedom/capacity of citizens to acquire, hold, dispose property, not concrete rights to specific property (which is under Article 31)

anchor.surface_text: Sub-clause (f) of clause (1) of article 19 has, in my opinion, no application to the case. That article enumerates certain freedoms under the caption right to freedom and deals with those great and basic rights which are recognised and guaranteed as the natural rights inherent in the status of a citizen of a free country.

arguments.claim: Article 31(1) and (2) must be read together; deprivation under (1) refers to acquisition/taking possession under (2); rejects mutually exclusive view and police power importation

anchor.surface_text: Article 31(1) formulates the fundamental right in negative form prohibiting the deprivation of property except by authority of law. ... Clauses (1) and (2) of article 31 are thus not mutually exclusive in scope and content, but should, in my view, be read together and understood as dealing with the same subject

arguments.claim: Section 7 does not effect deprivation of property under Article 31; abridgment not substantial (curtailed ejectment but allows rent enhancement)

anchor.surface_text: On this view of the meaning and effect of article 31, the question is whether section 7 read with section 4 of the amending Act infringes the fundamental right of the respondent under that article. ... I find it difficult to hold that the abridgement sought to be effected retrospectively of the rights of a purchaser at a revenue sale is so substantial as to amount to a deprivation of his property within the meaning of article 31(1) and (2).

arguments.claim: Restriction under section 7 is reasonable under Article 19(5); retrospectivity, no price abatement relevant but outweighed by public interest factors (hardships, evictions, ordinance, pending cases, rent enhancement)

anchor.surface_text: the cumulative effect of the foregoing facts which were not placed before the High Court much outweighs the consideration of the pecuniary loss of the respondent, Subodh Gopal Bose, as the auction-purchaser and in the circumstances the infliction of the loss of the right to eject under-tenants can only be regarded as a reasonable restriction permitted by article 19(5)

arguments.claim: Impugned section violates Article 31(2) as it takes away property right (to eject) without compensation

anchor.surface_text: An alternative argument, however, has been raised by learned advocate for the respondent, Subodh Gopal Bose, that the impugned section violates the fundamental right secured to him by article 31(2) of the Constitution and is, therefore, void under article 13(1). The contention, shortly put, is that the right conferred by the old section 37 to avoid and annul the under-tenures and to eject the under-tenants is, by itself, property

court_response_anchor.surface_text: declaration are, that it may cram Government in its useful exertions. But the evil of this is short-lived, moderate and reparable. The inconveniences

arguments.court_reasoning: No deprivation under Article 31 as abridgment not substantial

arguments.claim: High Court erred in reasonableness assessment due to lack of evidence on evils (no statement of objects, no pending cases data); now shown reasonable

anchor.surface_text: It is, indeed, very unfortunate that several important matters which would have assisted the High Court in arriving at a right conclusion as to the reasonableness of the restrictions imposed by the impugned section were not brought to the notice of the High Court.

arguments.claim: Retrospectivity alone does not make restriction unreasonable under Article 19(5)

anchor.surface_text: While I see some force in this argument I am, nevertheless, not convinced that the fact of the statute being given retrospective operation may not be properly taken into consideration in determining the reasonableness of the restriction imposed in the interest of the general public.

holdings.text: Article 19(1)(f) has no application to concrete rights of specific property; it declares the general freedom or capacity of citizens to acquire, hold and dispose of property.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-clause (f) of clause (1) of article 19 has, in my opinion, no application to the case. That article enumerates certain freedoms under the caption right to freedom and deals with those great and basic rights which are recognised and guaranteed as the natural rights inherent in the status of a citizen of a free country.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual and purposive interpretation distinguishing general freedoms in Art 19 from specific property protections in Art 31; analogies to US privileges/immunities and UN Declaration; avoids double protection and harmonizes citizen/non-citizen differences.

holdings.text: Clauses (1) and (2) of Article 31 are not mutually exclusive but must be read together as dealing with protection against deprivation by requiring authority of law, public purpose, and compensation for acquisition/taking possession.

anchor.surface_text: Article 31(1) formulates the fundamental right in negative form prohibiting the deprivation of property except by authority of law. It implies that a person may be deprived of his property by authority of law. Article 31(2) prohibits the acquisition or taking possession of property for a public purpose under any law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects Das J.'s obiter in Chiranjit Lal viewing clauses as exclusive/police power; protects against arbitrary legislative/executive deprivation; scheme of Constitution limits eminent domain; no importation of US police power.

holdings.text: Section 7 read with Section 4 of the amending Act does not infringe Article 31 as the abridgment of ejectment rights is not substantial deprivation (allows rent enhancement as countervailing benefit).

anchor.surface_text: On this view of the meaning and effect of article 31, the question is whether section 7 read with section 4 of the amending Act infringes the fundamental right of the respondent under that article. ... I find it difficult to hold that the abridgement sought to be effected retrospectively of the rights of a purchaser at a revenue sale is so substantial as to amount to a deprivation of his property within the meaning of article 31(1) and (2).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies deprivation test: substantial if withholds possession/enjoyment, impairs use, reduces value; here curtailment offset by rent enhancement; compares old/new s.37.

holdings.text: The restriction imposed by Section 7 on the right to eject under-tenants is reasonable under Article 19(5) in interests of general public.

anchor.surface_text: the cumulative effect of the foregoing facts which were not placed before the High Court much outweighs the consideration of the pecuniary loss of the respondent, Subodh Gopal Bose, as the auction-purchaser and in the circumstances the infliction of the loss of the right to eject under-tenants can only be regarded as a reasonable restriction permitted by article 19(5)

holdings.reasoning_summary: Multi-factor reasonableness test (nature of right, purpose, urgency, disproportion, conditions); considers objects/reasons, ordinance urgency, pending cases, rent enhancement, high land values outweighing retrospectivity/no price abatement.

holdings.text: Section 7 of the West Bengal Revenue Sales (Amendment) Act, 1950 is constitutional and valid; High Court judgment declaring it void is set aside.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside. The first respondent will pay the costs of this appeal incurred by the appellant here and in the lower Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings on Arts 19/31 uphold s.7; appeal allowed.

holdings.text: American doctrine of police power is not recognized in the Indian Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: This deprivation of property is supported in the United States of America as an exercise of police power. This deprivation of property is different from acquisition or taking of possession of property which goes by the name of eminent domain m the American law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitution distributes powers per lists; rejects due process antidote; eminent domain expressly granted/limited.

holdings.text: Retrospectivity of legislation is a factor but not decisive in determining reasonableness under Article 19(5).

anchor.surface_text: While I see some force in this argument I am, nevertheless, not convinced that the fact of the statute being given retrospective operation may not be properly taken into consideration in determining the reasonableness of the restriction imposed in the interest of the general public.

holdings.reasoning_summary: May be considered alongside other factors like urgency.

holdings.text: No deprivation under Article 31(2) as right to eject is not itself 'property' taken away without compensation.

anchor.surface_text: An alternative argument, however, has been raised by learned advocate for the respondent, Subodh Gopal Bose, that the impugned section violates the fundamental right secured to him by article 31(2) of the Constitution and is, therefore, void under article 13(1).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects respondent's claim; abridgment not acquisition.

precedents.cited_holding: Article 31(1) permits deprivation by authority of law; Article 31(2) for acquisition with compensation

anchor.surface_text: of. Punjab Province v. Daulat Singh and Other 1  and the reasonableness of such restrictions being brought under judicial review. For all these reasons, I am of opinion that under the scheme of the Constitution, all those broad and basic freedoms inherent in the status of a citizen as a free man are embodied and protected from invasion by the State under clause  1 of article 19, the powers of State regulation of those freedoms in public interest being defined in relation to each of those freedoms by clauses  2  to  6  of that article, while rights of private property are separately dealt with and their protection provided for in article 31, the cases where social companytrol and regulation companyld extend to the deprivation of such rights being indicated in para.  ii of subclause  b  of clause  5  of article 31.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside. The first respondent will pay the costs of this appeal incurred by the appellant here and in the lower Court.

Article 31(1) formulates the fundamental right in negative form prohibiting the deprivation of property except by authority of law. It implies that a person may be deprived of his property by authority of law. Article 31(2) prohibits the acquisition or taking possession of property for a public purpose under any law
In the result, the appeal is allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside. The first respondent will pay the costs of this appeal incurred by the appellant here and in the lower Court.

On this view of the meaning and effect of article 31, the question is whether section 7 read with section 4 of the amending Act infringes the fundamental right of the respondent under that article. ... I find it difficult to hold that the abridgement sought to be effected retrospectively of the rights of a purchaser at a revenue sale is so substantial as to amount to a deprivation of his property within the meaning of article 31(1) and (2).
In the result, the appeal is allowed and the judgment of the High Court is set aside. The first respondent will pay the costs of this appeal incurred by the appellant here and in the lower Court.
